etymologies: early 18th century; earliest use found in William Sutherland (fl. 1711–1717). From rib + band. Perhaps a folk-etymological alteration of ribbon, compare ribbon and the formal overlap with ribband riband, but it is perhaps more likely that ribbon shows influence from this word

definitions: Any of the long narrow strips of timber, etc., fixed longitudinally to the ribs of a ship to keep them in position until the external planking or plating is added.
A square timber fastened on the outer side of the launch cradle to prevent it from slipping outwards.

etymologies: early 19th century; earliest use found in Shipwright's Vade-mecum. From ribband

definitions: To secure (a frame, a boat, etc.) with ribbands.
